Summary Mark Rivera has a PhD from the Kellogg School of Management. His research draws from sociology, social-psychology, and statistical physics to understand how people form social networks and how these connections affect creativity, achievement, and job-satisfaction for people and for organizations. 
 
Mark has taught classes on Management, Social Networks, & Negotiations at the Kellogg School of Management and has lectured and consulted on the use of Social Network Data at Zynga, Google, a fortune 500 consumer goods manufacturer, IDEO and the Stanford Graduate School of Business. Specialties:Data analysis, Social Network Theory and Methodologies, Survey Design and Implementation, Electronic Data Processing, Complex Systems Theory. Experience People Analyst & Data Scientist Google January 2010  – Present (5 years 8 months) Decision Support Engineering Analyst Google June 2010  –  September 2010  (4 months) Conducted extensive statistical analyses on a large social network composed of millions of independent social interactions. Analyses were targeted at understanding how people’s position in social networks affects their behavior and how certain behaviors are contagious through social connections. Co-Founder ZotStock.com 2008  –  2009  (1 year) In 2006 I raised capital from several investors and formed ZotStock.com – a startup designed to provide an online-forum for recreational investors to submit stock picks and opinions. As the founder of the company I collaborated intensely with website designers and outside researchers to build a website and to design a predictive algorithm designed to aggregate thousands of independent stock predictions. ZotStock.com built on theories from crowd-sourcing and collective intelligence to derive stock predictions from the aggregated opinions a population of independent viewpoints. Experience CTO, Co-Founder Sociogramics Inc 2012  – Present (3 years) Mountain View, CA Sociogramics' vision is to return character and community to the core practices of financial institutions with an emphasis on the 80+ million in the U.S. who are unbanked, under-banked and those new to credit (such as recent immigrants and youth). Benefits to financial institutions, such as credit granters, depositories and insurers include increased lifetime account value, real-time life event insights, deepened customer engagement, fraud prevention and reduced delinquencies. Sociogramics was founded by serial entrepreneur and champion of social good, Gary Kremen (founder of both Match.Com and Clean Power Finance), and is backed by a consortium of leading national venture capital funds. Senior Software Engineer Netflix 2010  –  2012  (2 years) Built 100% of the new framework for building movie ranking systems within Netflix. As a result of testing the system (version 1), became the customer default experience on July 4th 2011. One CEO comment was "Reed commented, in his usual style as a question to Neil, that we have never seen such high [customer] retention gain for any test in the past". Another CEO comment was that customer retention was equivalent to spending an additional $25million/month on streaming content. Version 2 has 200% higher performance than version 1. Page 7 of the quarter 4 2011 investor letter included the following "Finally, we had several personalization algorithm breakthroughs for how we sort titles in each category, making it easier for our members to find movies and TV shows they’ll love." Software Engineer/Decision Support Engineering Analyst Google 2006  –  2010  (4 years) Mountain View, CA Member of the fraud/abuse team for Google checkout, adsense and adwords.

Principal Scientist Fair Isaac Corporation 2003  –  2006  (3 years) San Diego Principal Investigator for U.S. government BRAHMA III contract. Senior Research Scientist Motorola Human Interface Labs 1999  –  2003  (4 years) Palo Alto, CA Added discriminative training and input transforms to the Motorola software tools. Consultant to the eSensor DNA array product group – part of Motorola Life Sciences (http://www.motorola.com/lifesciences/esensor). I am the sole investigator in this project. My original project proposal was used by life sciences to obtain a NIMA grant. Approximately $150,000 of this was given to our site for payment for my services. The project was a proposal to improve the signal detection algorithm. This detector algorithm analyzes the electrical signals from the electrochemical cell and infers the presence or absence of targeted DNA sequences. Our current detector has 4 times more sensitivity, is 1/10 of the size and is 20 times faster than the baseline life sciences implementation.
